inputs:
Q: Which of the following sentences relating to argument does not use metaphorical language that could also be applied to war?
  choice: He killed his arguments with deft reasoning.
  choice: If you use that strategy, he will wipe you out.
  choice: He did not address my arguments.
  choice: He shot down all of my arguments.
A:
targets: He did not address my arguments.
multiple_choice_targets: If you use that strategy, he will wipe you out.
He shot down all of my arguments.
He killed his arguments with deft reasoning.
He did not address my arguments.

inputs:

  choice: She’s the top dog at the firm.
A:
targets: She’s the top dog at the firm.
multiple_choice_targets: He's a big man in the garment industry.
He's a giant among writers.
That was only a little white lie.
She’s the top dog at the firm.

multiple_choice_targets: The argument is clear.
The reasons for the decision were murky.
It's a transparent argument.
The discussion was opaque.

Q: Which of the following sentences relating to life does not use metaphorical language that could also be applied to gambling?
  choice: If you play your cards right, you can be successful in life.
  choice: The president was indifferent to the lives of the citizens.

A:
targets: The president was indifferent to the lives of the citizens.
multiple_choice_targets: If you play your cards right, you can be successful in life.
He bluffs his way through life.
The president is playing it close to his chest, but many lives hang on his decision.

A:
targets: We will apply the theory in practice.
multiple_choice_targets: We need to buttress the theory.
The theory will either stand or fall.

Q: Which of the following sentences relating to life does not use metaphorical language that could also be applied to gambling?
  choice: He’s been a real loser his whole life.

targets: The news that he would be a father left him speechless.

My whole life, he’s never been someone I can count on when the chips are down.
